text: In Greek mythology, Physcus (Ancient Greek: Φύσκος Physkos) or Physcius, was a king of Locris and son of Amphictyon and ChthonopatraEustathius on Homer, p. 277 and father of Locrus.Plutarch, Quaestiones Graecae 15 In some accounts, however, he was called the grandson of Amphictyon through Aetolus.Stephanus of Byzantium, s. v. PhyskosPseudo-Scymnus, Circuit of the Earth 587 ff. == Notes == == References == * Lucius Mestrius Plutarchus, Moralia with an English Translation by Frank Cole Babbitt. Cambridge, MA. Harvard University Press. London. William Heinemann Ltd. 1936. Online version at the Perseus Digital Library. Greek text available from the same website. * Stephanus of Byzantium, Stephani Byzantii Ethnicorum quae supersunt, edited by August Meineike (1790-1870), published 1849. A few entries from this important ancient handbook of place names have been translated by Brady Kiesling. Online version at the Topos Text Project. Category:Kings in Greek mythology
title: Physcus (mythology)
